item.title: No Many‚Äôs Sky Dev Jokes About Once Human Allegedly Stealing Their Assets
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this week, a post on the official No Man‚Äôs Sky subreddit highlighted what clearly looks like some digital theft. Some premium cosmetics in the free-to-play survival game Once Human look virtually identical to teleporters in space exploration game No Man‚Äôs Sky.

While a circular object that can teleport someone has been a staple of science fiction since at least the film Stargate, the more you look at these two 3D assets, the more similarities you‚Äôll spot; they‚Äôre virtually indistinguishable save for a different color theme. Managing director for NMS dev Hello Games, Sean Murray, was one of the many internet denizens who took note (h/t GamesRadar). Though instead of expressing outrage, he‚Äôs taken a more playful approach, pointing out an oversight in the original design.

‚ÄúJokes on them‚Äù Murray wrote on X, ‚Äúwe forgot to LOD those rivets üòÖ‚Äù

jokes on them ‚Äì we forgot to LOD those rivets üòÖ https://t.co/XYvgdFXLas pic.twitter.com/KXRD3F5X1i

‚Äî Sean Murray (@NoMansSky) December 2, 2025

So if the assets are indeed ripped from No Man‚Äôs Sky, it will come with some very unoptimized geometry for Once Human to wrestle with.

The heck is a LOD?

‚ÄúLOD‚Äù stands for ‚Äúlevel of detail.‚Äù Various objects in any given 3D game will have different LODs depending on how far away from the object a viewer is. The further you are, the less detail there is on the object. This aids in rendering and stress on the machine producing the geometry. There‚Äôs no sense in having a fully detailed 3D object if you‚Äôre many miles away. Here‚Äôs a video demonstrating the technique in Breath of the Wild:

So next time you‚Äôre playing a massive open-world game, now you know why objects look a little funny from a vast distance‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôre playing Once Human and looking at some allegedly stolen assets.

item.title: Kotaku Is Looking for Freelance Contributors
item.content:encoded:
Kotaku is looking for quick, sharp, and talented writers to help us cover the most interesting stories in gaming, from companies and communities to new releases and the latest trends. 

Freelancers will regularly contribute weekly reporting, analysis, and original features about the world of video games. This includes everything from the news of the day and smart takes on emerging conversations to fascinating scoops from weird corners of the internet or games that only you are paying attention to. 

Please reach out if:

  • You write sharp, accessible stories about everything from Take-Two‚Äôs quarterly earnings to why a gacha game is apologizing for ‚Äúcrab hands‚Äù
  • You have a punchy writing style, file clean copy, and are familiar with Kotaku‚Äôs general tone and subject areas
  • You can pitch and write timely news hits and short analysis pieces that connect the dots for readers on the biggest debates and events of the week
  • You‚Äôre eager to collaborate with other editors and writers to ensure our coverage is fast, fair, and full of voice
  • You have a keen news sense and can identify stories that our readers care about and no one else is covering
  • You have the editorial sensibility to know when a story needs speed, when it needs depth, and when it needs both

Details

  • Freelance / Remote
  • Competitive per-story rate starting at $50 per news post

**To apply, please email a resume, short cover letter outlining story and coverage ideas, and 3-5 clips to [email protected]**

item.title: Where Winds Meet Players Are Finding Clever And Sexy Ways To Screw With The Game‚Äôs AI NPCs
item.content:encoded:
Whether we wanted it or not, we‚Äôve stepped into a world where AI is increasingly sneaking into our games. Free-to-play multiplayer Steam hit Where Winds Meet is one of the latest examples, using an LLM-based chatbot for many of its NPCs that players can talk with. Or flirt with. Or ‚Äúsocially‚Äù engineer into completing quests without actually doing the work by talking to them like Solid Snake.

Read More: Open-World RPG Where Winds Meet Has It All: Evil Geese, AI Chatbots, And A $40,000 Skin

Developed by Chinese-based Everstone Studio, Where Winds Meet is a veritable Mulligan stew of countless modern gaming conventions, as well as AI NPCs that trade scripted, canned lines of dialogue for, in theory anyway, a more dynamic and unpredictable experience. Others might describe it as lifeless. I‚Äôm inclined to agree, but the tech isn‚Äôt without its amusing quirks and exploits. One such player seems to have proven this by flirting with the tech until it‚Ä¶well, it did something raunchy enough for a Reddit mod to take it down (h/t The Gamer).

Though the screenshot taken by Reddit user Oglokes24 is now in horny jail, we can glean some context clues from the comments. The flirting seemed to involve Okglokes24 lying to an NPC to say that ‚Äúher husband died‚Äù and, well, whatever it was, one user replied: ‚ÄúYou should be locked up.‚Äù ‚ÄúSex minigame when?‚Äù reads another comment. ‚ÄúBan incoming,‚Äù states another.

Kotaku has reached out to Oglokes24 about the contents of the now-deleted screenshot.

AI‚Ä¶Chatbots?

Since LLMs hit the web, folks have been finding all sorts of ways to trick them into doing things they‚Äôre not supposed to. Insert that tech into a game, and it‚Äôs no surprise that people are finding ways to get it to do things it‚Äôs not really supposed to. That includes some clever players realizing that if you talk to Where Winds Meet‚Äôs AI chatbots as Solid Snake would, by restating various phrases back to the NPC as a question, you can bypass certain quest win conditions.

In a Reddit post documenting the so-called ‚ÄúMetal Gear method‚Äù (h/t PCGamesN), a user was able to end a quest just by rephrasing everything the NPC said back as a question.

Based on comments from other players, the tech behind these pseudo-sentient NPCs isn‚Äôt as sophisticated as something like ChatGPT, so it‚Äôs a bit easier to find ways to screw with it. While I admit the prospect of interacting with NPCs via natural language is neat, I certainly am unwilling to trade thoughtful, well-written characters for this junk.

item.title: Arc Raiders‚Äô Stair Slides Might Be The Greatest Thing In Gaming History
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôm a humble man with simple needs. It turns out what I really look for in games is a really good bumpity-bumpity-bumpity noise while sliding down a flight of stairs. If it weren‚Äôt already packed with a squillion other good reasons, this would still be enough on its own to have me booting up Arc Raiders.

Let‚Äôs not mince words: sliding down a flight of stairs is great. From bumping down the carpeted steps on my bottom as a child, to launching myself down headfirst on a sleeping bag as a teenager, it‚Äôs an ideal way to spend a wet afternoon before a trip to the ER. As an adult, however, my significantly less resilient frame tends to object to such antics, and falling down the stairs has become the stuff of nightmares, likely to bruise a bone such that I‚Äôll complain for a month. So thank goodness for Arc Raiders and its simulation of the joyful action.

In Arc, like so many first- and third-person shooters, when you hit the crouch/crawl button while sprinting, it plunges your character into a sliding skid that is primarily programmed into most games to look cool. However, in Embark Studio‚Äôs extraction shooter, the action has multiple benefits. First and foremost, there‚Äôs the looking cool, but beyond this, skidding is a fast way to descend hills without draining your stamina. In fact, you can actually regain stamina during a skid, and when well-timed, it‚Äôs the perfect means of escape from a feisty gang of angry drones. Run, crouch, and slide down the dusty slopes, then regain enough energy to sprint off into a nearby doorway at the bottom.

But it‚Äôs not until you attempt this move at the top of a flight of steps, whether they‚Äôre in a concrete bunker or from a metal walkway, that you discover the utter life-affirming joy that‚Äôs on offer here. Sliding down steps is the smoothest, most satisfying movement in a video game since Kingdom of Amalur: Reckoning‚Äòs forward roll. Its perfection is a combination of factors that I shall lay out for you, scientifically:

  1. It‚Äôs not just a gimmick, but a very effective means of movement, especially when trying to escape danger
  2. It‚Äôs an uninterrupted and effortless slide with no tiresome movement penalty at the end
  3. You go ‚Äúba-dada, ba-dada, ba-dada‚Äù as you bump down the stairs at such speed in the most rewarding aural element in all of gaming history

Sometimes when I‚Äôm playing, I‚Äôll see other players just running down stairs and not sliding, and I worry. I worry that either they don‚Äôt know, and thus the vital necessity of this article. Or far, far worse, they do know and yet choose not to. These are broken people, and we need to have a way to report them not for bad play, but for the emotional support they so desperately deserve.

Arc Raiders‚Äò stair slides are a deep pleasure in difficult times, a sublime all-rewarding action that delivers both function and form, and it would be a sin against all that is positive not to celebrate them.

item.title: Bose Flex Bluetooth Speaker Drops to All-Time Low on Amazon, Now Cheaper Than Budget Options
item.content:encoded:
Amazon is still running Cyber Monday prices well into December, so people who missed the first sales rush can still get the Bose SoundLink Flex at a lower price. This portable Bluetooth speaker is now $119 instead of the regular $149 price which means that premium Bose audio is now available at a mid-range price, where you would normally find speakers with bad sound quality.

See at Amazon

Great Sound

The SoundLink Flex has PositionIQ sensors that can tell if you‚Äôve put the speaker upright, flat, or hanging from its utility loop. It then automatically changes the audio output to keep the sound quality at its best no matter how the speaker is positioned. This awareness of space is important because speaker drivers send sound in a certain direction, and what sounds balanced when you‚Äôre standing up can sound muddy or thin when the speaker tips over. The onboard processing changes the audio profile in real time, so the speaker works the same whether it‚Äôs on a picnic table, in your shower, or clipped to your backpack while you hike.

Bose designed the acoustics around a custom transducer and two passive radiators that give the small enclosure (3.6 by 7.9 by 2.1 inches) a surprising bass response. The passive radiators vibrate in sync with the active driver, which makes the low-frequency output go beyond what the small cabinet volume would normally produce. This bass emphasis doesn‚Äôt drown out the mids and highs because Bose tuned the frequency response to keep vocals and instruments clear even at high volumes. With complex music, you‚Äôll be able to hear the different parts clearly instead of everything blending together into a mushy mess like cheaper portable speakers do.

The IP67 rating means that this speaker is truly waterproof, not just splash-proof like many of its competitors claim. It can also protect against dust and submersion up to one meter deep for 30 minutes. After a day at the beach, you can rinse it off under the faucet or let it float in the pool without worrying about water damage. The outside is covered in silicone, which protects against scratches, rust, and UV damage when the device is outside for a long time.

Bluetooth 5.3 lets you connect to your paired device wirelessly up to 30 feet away and uses less power than older versions of Bluetooth. This helps the battery last longer between charges, up to 12 hours. Bluetooth 5.3 has more bandwidth, which means that audio compression artifacts that can make sound tinny or distorted on lower-quality speakers are less likely to happen. With multipoint pairing, two devices can connect at the same time. This means that you and a friend can take turns controlling music without having to keep disconnecting and reconnecting through Bluetooth settings.

The speaker charges through USB-C instead of the older micro-USB standard which means you can use the same cable that charges new phones and laptops to charge the speaker. The battery can charge quickly to a partial charge when you need to leave but forgot to charge it overnight. The speaker is only 1.3 pounds, so you can easily fit it in a daypack without adding too much weight or bulk.

The SoundLink Flex is a strong competitor with brands that can‚Äôt match its combination of sound quality and durability because it costs $119, which is a lot less than what you‚Äôd normally pay for Bose audio quality. The $30 off might not seem like much compared to some holiday deals, but Bose doesn‚Äôt often offer big discounts on its speakers, so any price drop is important.

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Had A Big Launch, Game Pass Helped Make It Even Bigger
item.content:encoded:
Would Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 have been just as big without a Game Pass deal? Sandfall creative director creative director Guillaume Broche doesn‚Äôt seem to think so. On Wednesday, Microsoft crowned the RPG its most popular third-party Game Pass launch of 2025, and Broche thinks the marketing and word-of-mouth from subscribers trying the game for free helped propel it to being one of the year‚Äôs biggest hits.

‚ÄúFresh from sweeping the Golden Joysticks and poised to do the same at The Game Awards, Sandfall Interactive‚Äôs phenomenal debut RPG is one of the most buzzed-about releases of the year, so it should surprise no one when we announce that Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is the biggest new third-party game launch on Xbox Game Pass of 2025,‚Äù Microsoft announced in a new blog post. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs based on the number of unique users in the first 30 days of its availability, which means a huge number of Xbox players joined Maelle, Gustave, Esquie, and the gang on their journey right from the beginning.‚Äù

If that sounds a bit like Xbox trying to steal some credit for the game‚Äôs success, Broche doesn‚Äôt seem to think it‚Äôs completely unwarranted. ‚ÄúFrom being there to announce our game back in Summer 2024, to coming to the studio for the Developer Direct video in January, Xbox helped us get the word out there and reach a lot of players,‚Äù he said.

Being on Game Pass also let ‚Äúa lot of people try our game when maybe they might not have before.‚Äù The turn-based RPG genre has a lot of fans, but sometimes it might put people who prefer more real-time action games off. Game Pass lowered that barrier of entry. They could just try it and see how it feels. So a lot of curious players could start the game, explore Lumi√®re and the early game, and realize there‚Äôs a lot to enjoy here, even if they weren‚Äôt expecting it at first.‚Äù

That was back in April when Game Pass was still just $20 a month. If Clair Obscur were coming out today, players would need to shell out $30 a month to have that same barrier to entry lowered. The Game Awards frontrunner is a good example of a Game Pass deal working out for everyone involved, but is it just the exception that proves the rule? As the service gets more expensive and deals for most indie releases get smaller, it‚Äôs unclear if Game Pass can keep a good thing going or will continue to enshitify.

Microsoft says the service is profitable and generated $5 billion in revenue, but it also hasn‚Äôt released new subscriber numbers in over a year. Maybe the platform will land another Clair Obscur-sized hit out of nowhere in 2026, or maybe this year will be remembered as the one that Game Pass peaked in.
